etymologies: mid 18th century; earliest use found in Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. From post-classical Latin pyrophorus or its etymon ancient Greek πυροϕόρος bearer of sacrificial fire from πυρο- + -ϕόρος

definitions: A substance capable (especially in a finely divided state) of igniting spontaneously on exposure to air.

notes.text: The term originally denoted a specific pyrophoric substance (in full "Homberg's pyrophorus"), made by heating alum with lampblack, starch, sugar, or flour.

definitions: In form Pyrophorus. A genus of strongly luminescent fireflies of the family Elateridae, found mainly in neotropical America.
